title: Functions and Datasets for the Data Science Course at IBAW
text: Windows Mac Users can download installer operating system https://cran.r-project.org/. Windows, installation possible also non-admin users. Mac users may also need install XQuartz. Linux users find instructions installation Debian, Fedora/Redhat, Ubuntu link. Note official package sources may contain outdated version R, usually current version can installed source. Make sure install version 4.0 newer.

title: Functions and Datasets for the Data Science Course at IBAW
text: use RStudio IDE course. can download link. Usually, easiest use installer operating system. However, don’t admin access computer, instead download appropriate zip-file / tarball. Windows, extract zip-file folder write access. executable file located bin/rstudio.exe. run RStudio first time, select R version want use. Usually, dialogue box list available R versions choose. , click “Browse…” navigate folder installed R.

title: Functions and Datasets for the Data Science Course at IBAW
text: use variety R Packages course. set , first install ibawds run following install additional packages: asked install missing packages. Confirm install . Note may take 30 minutes depending system configuration.

what: Cluster Data According to Centres and Recompute Centres — cluster_with_centers
title: Cluster Data According to Centres and Recompute Centres — cluster_with_centers
text: given dataset given centres, cluster_with_centers() assigns data point closest centre recomputes centres mean points assigned class. initial set random cluster centres can obtained init_rand_centers(). functions can used visualise mechanism k-means.

title: Cluster Data According to Centres and Recompute Centres — cluster_with_centers
code: cluster_with_centers(data, centers)  init_rand_centers(data, n, seed = sample(1000:9999, 1))

title: Cluster Data According to Centres and Recompute Centres — cluster_with_centers
text: data data.frame containing variables used clustering. centers data.frame giving centres clusters. must number columns data. n number cluster centres create seed random seed reproducibility

title: Cluster Data According to Centres and Recompute Centres — cluster_with_centers
text: list containing two tibbles: centers: new centres clusters computed cluster assignment given centres cluster: cluster assignment point data using centres passed function

title: Cluster Data According to Centres and Recompute Centres — cluster_with_centers
code: # demonstrate k-means with iris data # keep the relevant columns iris2 <- iris[, c("Sepal.Length", "Petal.Length")]  # initialise the cluster centres clust <- init_rand_centers(iris2, n = 3, seed = 2435)  # plot the data with the cluster centres library(ggplot2) ggplot(iris2, aes(x = Sepal.Length, y = Petal.Length)) +  geom_point(data = clust$centers, aes(colour = factor(1:3)),             shape = 18, size = 6) +  geom_point() +  scale_colour_brewer(palette = "Set1")   # assign clusters and compute new centres clust_new <- cluster_with_centers(iris2, clust$centers)  # plot the data with clustering clust$cluster <- clust_new$cluster voronoi_diagram(clust, x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Petal.Length",                 data = iris2)   # plot the data with new cluster centres clust$centers <- clust_new$centers voronoi_diagram(clust, x = "Sepal.Length", y = "Petal.Length",                 data = iris2, colour_data = FALSE)   # this procedure may be repeated until the algorithm converges

what: Plot Density and Distribution Function With Markings — distribution_plot
title: Plot Density and Distribution Function With Markings — distribution_plot
text: Create plots density distribution functions probability distribution. possible mark points shade area curve.

title: Plot Density and Distribution Function With Markings — distribution_plot
code: distribution_plot(   fun,   range,   ...,   points = NULL,   var = "x",   title = "Verteilungsfunktion",   is_discrete = NULL )  density_plot(   fun,   range,   ...,   from = NULL,   to = NULL,   points = NULL,   var = "x",   title = "Dichte",   is_discrete = NULL )

title: Plot Density and Distribution Function With Markings — distribution_plot
text: fun density distribution function takes quantiles first argument. range numeric vector length two giving range quantiles plotted. ... arguments passed fun(). points numeric vector giving quantiles function marked red dot (continuous) red bar (discrete). var character giving name quantile variable. used label axes. title character giving title plot is_discrete logical indicating whether discrete distribution. discrete distributions, bar plot created. omitted, function tries automatically determine, whether distributions discrete. case fail, set argument explicitly. , numeric values giving start end range area density shaded (continuous) bars drawn red (discrete). one two values given, shading start negative infinity go positive infinity, respectively.

title: Plot Density and Distribution Function With Markings — distribution_plot
text: ggplot object

title: Plot Density and Distribution Function With Markings — distribution_plot
code: # plot density of the normal distribution density_plot(dnorm, c(-5, 7),              mean = 1, sd = 2,              to = 3)   # plot distribution function of the Poisson distribution distribution_plot(ppois, c(0, 12),                   lambda = 4,                   points = c(2, 6, 10),                   var = "y")

what: Find a Named Colour that is Similar to Any Given Colour — find_similar_colour
title: Find a Named Colour that is Similar to Any Given Colour — find_similar_colour
text: Find named colour similar given colour.

title: Find a Named Colour that is Similar to Any Given Colour — find_similar_colour
code: find_similar_colour(   colour,   distance = c("euclidean", "manhattan"),   verbose = interactive() )

title: Find a Named Colour that is Similar to Any Given Colour — find_similar_colour
text: colour colour specified one three forms: hexadecimal string form "#rrggbb" "#rrggbbaa", numeric vector length 3 numeric matrix dimensions c(3, 1), returned col2rgb(). Numeric values must 0 255. distance character indicating distance metric used. verbose additional output produced? shows RGB values input colour, similar named colour difference two.

title: Find a Named Colour that is Similar to Any Given Colour — find_similar_colour
text: character length one name similar named colour.

title: Find a Named Colour that is Similar to Any Given Colour — find_similar_colour
code: find_similar_colour("#d339da") #> [1] "mediumorchid" find_similar_colour(c(124, 34, 201)) #> [1] "purple3"  # suppress additional output find_similar_colour("#85d3a1", verbose = FALSE) #> [1] "darkseagreen3"  # use Manhattan distance find_similar_colour(c(124, 34, 201), distance = "manhattan") #> [1] "purple3"

title: Tables Used for Grading the Papers — grading_tables

what: Noisy Data From a Tenth Order Polygon — noisy_data
title: Noisy Data From a Tenth Order Polygon — noisy_data
text: Training test data create tenth order polynomial added noise. polynomial given $$f(x) = 2 x - 10 x^5 + 15 x^{10}$$ noise follows standard normal distribution. data can used demonstrate overfitting. inspired section II. B. high-bias, low-variance introduction Machine Learning physicists

title: Noisy Data From a Tenth Order Polygon — noisy_data
Noisy Data From a Tenth Order Polygon — noisy_data
text: list two tibbles two columns . \(x\) stands independent, \(y\) dependent variable. training data (noisy_data$train) contains 1000 rows, test data (noisy_data$test) 20 rows.

title: Noisy Data From a Tenth Order Polygon — noisy_data
text: P. Mehta et al., high-bias, low-variance introduction Machine Learning physicists Phys. Rep. 810 (2019), 1-124. arXiv:1803.08823 doi:10.1016/j.physrep.2019.03.001

what: Create a Random Vector With Fixed Correlation With Another Vector — rand_with_cor
title: Create a Random Vector With Fixed Correlation With Another Vector — rand_with_cor
text: rand_with_cor() creates vector random number correlation rho given vector y. Also mean standard deviation random vector can fixed user. default, equal mean standard deviation y, respectively.

title: Create a Random Vector With Fixed Correlation With Another Vector — rand_with_cor
code: rand_with_cor(y, rho, mu = mean(y), sigma = sd(y))

title: Create a Random Vector With Fixed Correlation With Another Vector — rand_with_cor
text: solution based answer whuber Cross Validated.

title: Create a Random Vector With Fixed Correlation With Another Vector — rand_with_cor
text: y numeric vector rho numeric value -1 1 giving desired correlation. mu numeric value giving desired mean sigma numeric value giving desired standard deviation

title: Create a Random Vector With Fixed Correlation With Another Vector — rand_with_cor
text: vector length y correlation rho y.

title: Create a Random Vector With Fixed Correlation With Another Vector — rand_with_cor
code: x <- runif(1000, 5, 8)  # create a random vector with positive correlation y1 <- rand_with_cor(x, 0.8) all.equal(cor(x, y1), 0.8) #> [1] TRUE  # create a random vector with negative correlation # and fixed mean and standard deviation y2 <- rand_with_cor(x, -0.3, 2, 3) all.equal(cor(x, y2), -0.3) #> [1] TRUE all.equal(mean(y2), 2) #> [1] TRUE all.equal(sd(y2), 3) #> [1] TRUE

what: Rescale Mean And/Or Standard Deviation of a Vector — rescale
title: Rescale Mean And/Or Standard Deviation of a Vector — rescale
text: Rescale Mean /Standard Deviation Vector

title: Rescale Mean And/Or Standard Deviation of a Vector — rescale
Rescale Mean And/Or Standard Deviation of a Vector — rescale
text: x numeric vector mu numeric value giving desired mean sigma numeric value giving desired standard deviation

title: Rescale Mean And/Or Standard Deviation of a Vector — rescale
text: numeric vector length x mean mu standard deviation sigma.

title: Rescale Mean And/Or Standard Deviation of a Vector — rescale
text: default, mean standard deviation changed, .e., rescale(x) identical x. value specified mu /sigma mean /standard deviation rescaled.

title: Rescale Mean And/Or Standard Deviation of a Vector — rescale
code: x <- runif(1000, 5, 8)  # calling rescale without specifying mu and sigma doesn't change anything all.equal(x, rescale(x)) #> [1] TRUE  # change the mean without changing the standard deviation x1 <- rescale(x, mu = 3) all.equal(mean(x1), 3) #> [1] TRUE all.equal(sd(x1), sd(x)) #> [1] TRUE  # rescale mean and standard deviation x2 <- rescale(x, mu = 3, sigma = 2) all.equal(mean(x2), 3) #> [1] TRUE all.equal(sd(x2), 2) #> [1] TRUE

Set Inf always print rows. tibble_print_min Number rows printed tibble tibble_print_max rows.

what: Create a Voronoi Diagram for a Clustering — voronoi_diagram
title: Create a Voronoi Diagram for a Clustering — voronoi_diagram
text: Create Voronoi diagram given clustering object.

title: Create a Voronoi Diagram for a Clustering — voronoi_diagram
code: voronoi_diagram(   cluster,   x,   y,   data = NULL,   show_data = !is.null(data),   colour_data = TRUE,   legend = TRUE,   point_size = 2,   linewidth = 0.7 )

title: Create a Voronoi Diagram for a Clustering — voronoi_diagram
text: cluster object containing result clustering, e.g., created kmeans(). must contain fields cluster centers. x, y character giving names variables plotted x- y-axis. data data used create clustering. provided, extension plot adapted data data points plotted unless suppressed specifying show_data = FALSE. show_data data points plotted? TRUE default data given. colour_data data points coloured according assigned cluster? legend colour legend clusters plotted? point_size numeric indicating size data points cluster centres. linewidth numeric indicating width lines separate areas clusters. Set 0 show lines .

title: Create a Voronoi Diagram for a Clustering — voronoi_diagram
text: function uses deldir package create polygons Voronoi diagram. code inspired ggvoronoi, can handle complex situations.

title: Create a Voronoi Diagram for a Clustering — voronoi_diagram
text: Garrett et al., ggvoronoi: Voronoi Diagrams Heatmaps ggplot2, Journal Open Source Software 3(32) (2018) 1096, doi:10.21105/joss.01096

title: Create a Voronoi Diagram for a Clustering — voronoi_diagram
Wine Quality — wine_quality
text: Physicochemical data quality ratings red white Portuguese Vinho Verde wines.

title: Wine Quality — wine_quality
Wine Quality — wine_quality
text: tibble 6497 rows 13 variables: colour colour wine; "red" (1'599) "white" (4'898) fixed_acidity tartaric acid per volume \(g/dm^3\) volatile_acidity acetic acid per volume \(g/dm^3\) citric_acid citric acid per volume \(g/dm^3\) residual_sugar residual sugar per volume \(g/dm^3\) chlorides sodium chloride per volume \(g/dm^3\) free_sulfur_dioxide free sulphur dioxide  per volume \(mg/dm^3\) total_sulfur_dioxide total sulphur dioxide per volume \(mg/dm^3\) density density \(g/dm^3\) pH pH value sulphates potassium sulphate per volume \(g/dm^3\) alcohol alcohol content per volume % quality quality score 0 (worst) 10 (best) determined sensory analysis.

title: Wine Quality — wine_quality
text: data available UC Irvine Machine Learning Repository. P. Cortez, . Cerdeira, F. Almeida, T. Matos J. Reis, Modeling wine preferences data mining physicochemical properties, Decision Support Systems 47(4) (2009), 547-553.
